industry experience.name: TechWolf
industry experience.summary: Interned in the Research team of this HR Tech scale-up company which uses AI&ML to offer insights into the skills of a company's workforce. My work focused on automatically growing the company's ontology of skills, an in-house dictionary of unique skills which sits at the very core of their product, as new industries emerge.

description.project: fine-tuned a pre-trained language model on a dataset of 1000 sentences that I labelled myself. The resulting IOB-labelling model helped discover new skill spans from free text. Once extracted, these were compared and matched to those already present in the company's ontology, using embedding cosine similarity. For any new (unmatched) skill, I automatically generated potential synonymous forms using traditional parsing methods and WordNet.
description.research: deep literature review in the fields of Psychology, Economics and HR, to help formalise the company's definition of skill.

industry experience.name: Microsoft
industry experience.summary: A 12-week remote internship with the FAST CAR Team working with the Contacts & People Relationships APIs for Office 365.

description.project: designed, implemented, and tested a C# mailbox processor to extract social-media accounts from a user's personal emails, infer the owners of the accounts, and add the data to that user's Contacts.
description.documentation: actively expanded the team's onboarding and technical documentation; I was praised for the quality of my work.
description.hacking: volunteered in company-wide hackathon for the charity DigiGirlz and helped prototype, implement, and pitch a Unity Game to teach basic networking principles to young girls.
description.networking and cooperation: in a remote context, I had to quickly learn the expertise of different individuals/teams and managed to coordinate people from far and wide to get the project done in time.

industry experience.name: J.P. Morgan & Chase
industry experience.summary: The internship was shortened, and made remote due to COVID-19.

description.training: was assessed in weekly coding tasks that were reviewed by my manager who provided high-quality feedback and mentorship.

description.front-end design: built a mock-up website to present some ideas for a new company website, and maintained the existing website.

description.community management: managed the company's social media channels via Buffer, created a series of animated advertising videos using Vyond, wrote blog articles and managed SEOs for Wordpress, collaborated with the development team to test and debug website.

awards.title: Best Insight (Honorable Mention)
awards.summary: Participated in the ASA DataFest, a data analysis competition, in a team of four. For this competition the Rocky Mountain Poison and Drug Safety Center was interested in discovering and identifying patterns of drug use, with particular attention paid to identifying misuse. The judges were impressed with our presentation and our choice to focus on maximum possible prison sentence, as well as how we compared the data provided with other data sources to get a sense of representativeness.

awards.title: "Procedurally-generated game" challenge winner
awards.awarder: Hack The Burgh 7, University of Edinburgh
awards.summary: Participated in the hackathon organised by the School of Informatics, and won the "Procedurally-generated game" sponsored by Craneware. See "Malfunctioning Penguin" in Projects.

projects.name: "Malfunctioning Penguin" Game
projects.summary: Group project completed during the 24-hour-long hackathon "Hack The Burgh 7" that was awarded best "Procedurally-generated game".

description.procedural-generation: the game generates an ice-slide on the sea from the frequency wave of user-inputted music files. Users press on the space bar to change a penguin's gliding direction (left to right or vice versa) to avoid falling into the water.
description.environmentally conscious: as the music progresses, the slide grows thinner, making the game more difficult, and showcasing the effects global warming on the melting ice-cap. Rubbish and sea-fauna are also depicted to show the animal suffering from water pollution.

projects.name: "r/roastme" Web Application
projects.summary: Group project completed during the 24-hour-long hackathon "Hack The Burgh 6". This full-stack web app allows a user to upload a picture to receive a personalised offensive "roast". The project was greatly praised for its originality but deemed too controversial to award.

description.machine learning: we first built a dataset of face encodings linked to top comments scraped from the subreddit r/roastme. The app returns a roast most relevant to user-uploads using the Python library ageitgey/face_recognition.
description.natural-language processing: although it was not added to the final app in time for the hack, we also worked on generating short rhyming poems based on the returned roasts.
